body: Thanks,.. I'll try that.. I need it on ubuntu.. I'll figure it out and release a package..

Also seeing this here. Just commenting out the offending `assert` let the build go on its way without issue. [The commit](https://github.com/conda/conda-build/commit/fe7f773010f4c8c200298c83a4164ca404626d52) which added the `is_obj` test, for context.

For most English grammar, negation follows the [auxillary or special verb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_grammar#Negation) used to connect the action. It's fine to keep, just thought it improved readability this way.

Hi @msarahan thanks for the reply. I neglected to include enough details: I'm rebuilding a package on Windows that I've previously build successfully, currently using:
```
conda                     4.3.24                   py35_0
conda-build               3.0.10           py35h689962e_0
```
My environment also included the `patch` package, version 2.5.9. When I tried to rebuild the same package I'd built previously, I received the error above. Here's what I see in the defaults channel for the package:

```
patch                        1.12.11                  py27_0  defaults
                             2.5                           0  defaults
                             2.5.9                         0  defaults
                          *  2.5.9                         1  defaults
```

I've created a simple repository containing a stripped down version of package that previously I was able to build:

  https://github.com/scw/netcdf-patch-example/

That should hopefully include enough details to reproduce the behavior. On my machine, that will consistently cause a crash in the patching phase, though conda-build still will try to continue after the failed patching. I've also updated the title, because the patch in question has LF line endings already. In the absence of an updated `patch` on anaconda.org which doesn't exhibit this behavior, I think for Windows, it makes sense to have `m2-patch` be 'the right way' to apply patches. On MacOS and Linux, it's either available out of the box or one apt-get away, but on Windows that's not the case. I was suggesting `m2-patch` as a dependency on Windows because it would simplify the workflow somewhat. If there are specific details of my environment which are causing this and it's not reproducible, this issue can be closed.

Perhaps a separate issue is that the documentation doesn't really communicate how to generate patches that conda-build can consume at the moment, I can open a separate documentation issue on that, and provide some suggested copy if that'd be useful. I've just been using `diff -u` and `git diff` to generate my patches, but I see that there are some more sophisticated options using e.g. `git format-patch` which may be worth documenting.

Thanks for all your great work on Conda!

Right, as it does for @ratstache it causes a full windows crash. The rest of conda build will  continue, without the patch being applied, but eventually hangs, requiring the process be killed. Here's the output of dos2unix on this patch file:
```
$ dos2unix -i hdf5.patch
       0      33       0  no_bom    text    hdf5.patch
```
So 33 LF (Unix) line breaks only. None of the files in the above repository have Windows-style line endings. I can confirm that this package builds for me on 2.1.17, but not on any of the 3.x versions I've tested.

@mingwandroid Yes, `m2-patch` is definitely the right answer. However, other users will still hit this if they happen to have `patch` which will still be used by `conda-build`. I recommend making `m2-patch` a requirement of conda-build when running on Windows.

I also hit this issue in a pipeline, and confirm `conda update --all` works. For many use cases, this should be resolved when the newer versions are bundled within the Miniconda installer and docker image.

is this documented somewhere? [this](http://conda.pydata.org/docs/building/environment-vars.html?highlight=template) is the most I could find.

e.g. is it possible to define a custom template to inherit from?

I realized it was incomplete. But the solution involves creating _another_ copy of a large data file. Is there a way to tell conda not to perform this check at all? --I mean is there a way to tell conda that it's just a static data file and doesn't need to be modified?
got it working on python3. I did a couple of force-pushes so I wouldn't have 10 commits fixing the issues. Looks like appveyor is failing for other reasons.
cheers!

I made this PR because I couldn't build a (data) package before on my laptop with 8GB of memory. After this, I could build much larger recipes. 
Granted, it's a rare use-case since most software packages (and files) are tiny. So the severity is exactly dependent on the size of the package.

I guess the solution would be to try mmap, catch the OSError and just read the file into memory. And then have a check to not call close() on the string.
should be an easy fix. I'll have a PR tomorrow.
let me know any feedback on the pr in #869
this is the related change in binstar_client that takes advantage of the change here: https://github.com/Anaconda-Server/anaconda-client/pull/311
I see a huge difference on e.g. https://anaconda.org/bspuu/reference/files with both changes. I will update the PR sort info/ to be first (and then by size) tomorrow morn.
this should be good to go.
Yes, please make much longer than 128.
yes, that's me. looks like we can just add .decode('ascii')  to the write. trying to figure out how to trigger this error in the existing tests...
I thinks it's with detect_binary_files_with_prefix: true
aye. but reading that is where I got the idea... :|
I tried to get the tests to fail in #893, but no luck. This should fix #889, but any insight on making a test break would be great.

I'm probably misusing conda. I'm trying to specify a dependency for the pre-link.sh script. It seems like a PATH is not set correctly. Here's a meta.yaml (where samtools is in bioconda channel):

```
# fake/meta.yaml
package:
  name: fake
  version: '123'

requirements:
  build:
  - samtools
  run:
  - samtools
```

and a pre-link.sh

```
# fake/pre-link.sh
samtools --help
```

when I run `conda build ./fake` there are no problems and it installs `samtools` and the dependencies into $CONDA_ROOT/envs/_build/bin/samtools
It builds the .bz2, when I run: 

```
conda install $CONDA_ROOT/conda-bld/linux-64/fake-123-0.tar.bz2
```

then it shows:

```
/pkgs/fake-123-0/bin/.fake-pre-link.sh: line 1: samtools: command not found
Error: pre-link failed: fake-123-0
```

ok. thanks. with conda@master, I get:

```
anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda/install.py", line 717, in extract
    rec = package_cache()[dist]
KeyError: 'fake-123-0'
```

The actual key seems to be `<unknown>::fake-123-0`
I think this might be related to: https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/2358 and https://github.com/conda/conda/pull/2369

I am able to get conda master to work with these changes. Is there a better way to address this upstream?

``` patch
$ git diff
diff --git a/conda/install.py b/conda/install.py
index 86a6c7b..98785d8 100644
--- a/conda/install.py
+++ b/conda/install.py
@@ -693,6 +693,9 @@ def is_extracted(dist):
     for fn in package_cache().get(dist, {}).get('dirs', ()):
         return fn

+    if not dist.startswith("<unknown>::"):
+        return is_extracted("<unknown>::" + dist)
+
 def rm_extracted(dist):
     """
     Removes any extracted versions of the given package found in the cache.
@@ -713,7 +716,11 @@ def extract(dist):
     Extract a package, i.e. make a package available for linkage. We assume
     that the compressed package is located in the packages directory.
     """
-    rec = package_cache()[dist]
+    try:
+        rec = package_cache()[dist]
+    except KeyError:
+        rec = package_cache()["<unknown>::" + dist]
+
     url = rec['urls'][0]
     fname = rec['files'][0]
     assert url and fname
```

I see lots of "unknown" packages in my package cache, e.g.

```
'<unknown>::conda-3.19.0-py27_0', '<unknown>::conda-env-2.4.5-py27_0', '<unknown>::fake-123-0', '<unknown>::openssl-1.0.2d-0', '<unknown>::pip-7.1.2-py27_0', '<unknown>::pycosat-0.6.1-py27_0', '<unknown>::pycrypto-2.6.1-py27_0', '<unknown>::python-2.7.11-0', '<unknown>::pyyaml-3.11-py27_1', '<unknown>::readline-6.2-2', '<unknown>::requests-2.9.0-py27_0', '<unknown>::setuptools-18.8.1-py27_0', '<unknown>::sqlite-3.8.4.1-1', '<unknown>::tk-8.5.18-0', '<unknown>::wheel-0.26.0-py27_1', '<unknown>::yaml-0.1.6-0'
```
not sure if this helps, but those are likely the ones I installed with `python setup.py install` or `pip`.
cheers.

actually, with the example above, I still get:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/data/miniconda2/bin/conda", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('conda==3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa', 'console_scripts', 'conda')()
  File "/data/miniconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda-3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa-py2.7.egg/conda/cli/main.py", line 120, in main
    args_func(args, p)
  File "/data/miniconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda-3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa-py2.7.egg/conda/cli/main.py", line 127, in args_func
    args.func(args, p)
  File "/data/miniconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda-3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa-py2.7.egg/conda/cli/main_install.py", line 62, in execute
    install.install(args, parser, 'install')
  File "/data/miniconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda-3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa-py2.7.egg/conda/cli/install.py", line 193, in install
    misc.explicit(args.packages, prefix, verbose=not args.quiet)
  File "/data/miniconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda-3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa-py2.7.egg/conda/misc.py", line 123, in explicit
    execute_actions(actions, index=index, verbose=verbose)
  File "/data/miniconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda-3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa-py2.7.egg/conda/plan.py", line 554, in execute_actions
    inst.execute_instructions(plan, index, verbose)
  File "/data/miniconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda-3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa-py2.7.egg/conda/instructions.py", line 137, in execute_instructions
    cmd(state, arg)
  File "/data/miniconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/conda-3.19.1.dev654+g91847aa-py2.7.egg/conda/instructions.py", line 47, in FETCH_CMD
    fetch_pkg(state['index'][arg + '.tar.bz2'])
KeyError: 'local::fake-123-0.tar.bz2'
```

the commands to reproduce are just:

```
conda build ./fake
conda install $(conda info --root)/conda-bld/linux-64/fake-123-0.tar.bz2
```

for me `state['index']` is empty at that point.

here is a standalone bash script to recreate:

```
set -eo pipefail

rm -rf fake && mkdir -p fake
echo "
package:
  name: fake
  version: '123'

" > fake/meta.yaml

echo "ls -lh" > fake/pre-link.sh

conda build fake
conda install $(conda info --root)/conda-bld/*/fake-123-0.tar.bz2
```
